reviewText: Wow, look at the price. Some of us were around watching for the original airing. Some watched reruns. Now everyone, young and old, can get back into this nostalgic, but never dated ROOTS experience. This set is 4 DVD (2-sided) 7 episodes plus a bonus and over 11 1/2 hours of history presented by over 50 television and film stars. This takes the Kunta Kinte family of Alex Haley's story "Roots" and "Search" from the Civil War, the period where the TV phenomenon "Roots" ended, to modern day. The story is all about family. "The Next Generation" is as compelling as "Roots", the beginning. Both are highly recommended.And now it comes as an economical bargain. No where will you find such star power, such action and adventure, such portrayal of American history, such devotion to family, a tale of love, devotion, sorrow, sacrifice, achievement, chance, loss, well if there is an emotion to experience it has been included several times in this set.For those who have seen it, it is a blast from the past and just as rewarding as the first viewing. For those who have not had the experience, likely due to a young age, this will make an impression on your life you will never forget, just like your parents and grandparents had. Never will this type of thing be duplicated.Roots and this sequel will eventually fall into the category that holds achievements like The Ten Commandments, Gone With the Wind, and other masterpiece visuals that become a must-see for every generation to come.
summary: BARGAIN PRICE FOR A CLASSIC TV EXPERIENCE
Title: N/A

reviewerName: Jacques COULARDEAU "A soul doctor, so to say"
reviewText: This TV mini-series has become a classic in some twenty or thirty years and it deserves to be, both in its first part and in its second part. Yet the quality of the filming and editing has aged and the film is not served by the fact it was done for television that tends to show  too many close-ups and to avoid vast  rapid movements and wide landscapes. But it has become a classic by the theme it deals with.The second part takes us to the 1960s and is telling the history of the USA after the Civil War as much at least as the history of this family. So we see the reconstruction period, and then the emergence of the Ku Klux Klan, the imposition of segregation, the First World War, the New Deal and the Second World War, and then the post war period. In this second series that ends with the real author as the main character, Haley himself, I am amazed by the fact that it is more contemplative of the injustice coming up than really fighting against it. The only positive point is education. But if there is some kind of resistance it is always that of one person and not of the community. If in the 1930s, the subsidies voted by Congress to small farmers to help them survive the crisis and get even, blacks included, are systematically, for the blacks at least, hijacked by the land-owners to their own profit and if one black farmer manages to get his check it is the result of the private initiative of one man and the black farmer ends up in prison, wounded and under a prosecution that will keep him in prison for a while and his mules have been repossessed by the landowner and the little farmer has been totally pauperized and expelled from the county if not the state. If after the war there is some improvement the discourse is concentrating on the personal efforts of Alex Haley, his own personal way to some kind of wealth and grace. The closest we get to the struggle of the black community for the end of discrimination and more justice is a couple of scenes with Malcolm X and his assassination. But where is Martin Luther King, Rosa Parks and the collective massive fights and battles waged by the blacks, including against the Vietnam War. Even Kennedy is evoked as some kind of epiphenomenon that does not count for much, and his assassination is not even evoked. That has to lead to a real ego trip at the end and Alex Haley going back to Gambia and meeting with the griot of the village of his ancestors and hearing from his mouth the story that had been told from generation to generation in his family and meeting one last descendant who still has the name Kinte like the ancient ancestor Kunta Kinte. And Alex Haley himself adds a verbose conclusion about the importance of knowing one's ancestors. What a pride am I supposed to get from the fact that my ancestors were the serfs of a small nobleman who ended up in the French Academy under King Louis XV and whose name they all took during the revolution? That kind of nostalgia may make us unable to embrace the future today.Dr Jacques COULARDEAU, University Paris 1 Pantheon Sorbonne, University Paris 8 Saint Denis, University Paris 12 Créteil, CEGID
summary: Too much centered on one man in each generation

reviewText: Roots part 8 was seen by more people at the time of its airing than any other TV show in history; in fact, all 8 parts of the mini series made it into the top 12 of all time.The show was so phenomenal that the producers proceeded to make Roots: The Next Generations, a 7-part mini series picking up where Roots left off. The producers did a marvelous job, showcasing the struggles of black people in general while following the Kinte family-line all the way to Alex Haley himself.Though major black players like Malcom X were introduced, they did not garner enough story-time to be distractions.I strongly recommend that every American citizen watch Roots & its sequal, Roots: The Next Generations. Perhaps if current American hate mongers (e.g., Sean Hannerty, Rush Limbaugh, Tea Party activists, Sarah Palin, Michelle Bachman, etc.) were to watch these shows, a dash of humanity might overtake them a bit & soften their hatred of everyone who's not like themselves.

reviewText: Unfortunately, I never read the book "Roots" nor did I see the movie when it came out.  Recently I decided to buy DVDs of both "Roots" and "Up From Slavery".  As most are aware they are very powerful in documenting the horrors of innocent peoples snatched from their homeland in Africa, packed into the holds of sailing ships and sold to white plantation owners (and other wealthy people) in the New World.  Although it is heart wrenching, this important part of history needs to be kept alive so that it never, ever happens again.

reviewText: Ok it's not ROOTS, but it explains how the next generation of the Hailey family comes to be.Over all the story is believable and shows how hard it was for black Americans, before the civil rights bill was signed in the mid 1960's.Alex Hailey, played by James Earl Jones, traces his heritage back to Africa.Roots: The Next Generations
Title: N/A

reviewText: So much happened in so few years that the series needed to be a lot longer. It was very good and I learned a lot. Though it all happened within my lifetime, as a white person in a small Midwest town I was really unaware of most of it and was never the target of prejudice or violence. I am both embarrassed and ashamed at how little I knew of what Black people were experiencing at that time. I thought the part about Malcolm X was especially fascinating and wish there had been more. Now I have to get the film about him. Perhaps it's because I had just finished watching the entire ROOTS series, which seemed so complete, that this series seemed somehow lacking. But I did think it was excellent, though lacking a bit, and would recommend it to anyone.
Title: N/A

When a "very old"tom moore,voting,fight,and train ride,i like so much,very realistic,and the way he HELD the first grandchild to the sky/god i LOVE that so much pretty much traditional,that was 1 of the best parts in the ENTIRE movie.so nice.Hence:(just a few boring snoozin' parts)i.e. some of the first and second episode,was a snoozing-moment,lol but i watch nevertheles!)lolBut i do agree with most:IT WAS, NO WHERE AS GREAT-BEYOND IMAGINETHE ORIGINAL 1st Roots.I love original watch 2 days straight this xmas eve night,and dec.23 repeatedly..HOWEVER:i love and did not "struggle lol to watch" at all the third part,IMO(in my opinion)BEST with her the lovely talent,of IRENE CARA,with the handsome talented actor,Dorian Harewood! they were IMO the best..beyond in the entire series.i really did like also OSSIE DAVIS.I mean who could not.He is incredible.An,Incredible realistic SL there,great acting and even the scene between the"real alex" at the end almost,finding his people i tear up in mi eyes,but yea was no where NEAR the 1st,then again as my parents say,It is not suppose to be! but it was a great movie,well-done.and lastly:The younger CYNTHIA lovely woman,with Will Palmer marry scene was a riot! and i love seeing TOM MOORE OLD/Irene both of them were 2 of mi fave in the Original.But simon haley love story movin' on up with his wife was great from the timethey met.I love it..Simon Haley pix in real life,so handsome,and did not resemble,at all the actorDorian Harewood lol but i love dorian too,as a actor,each minute he was on,such LOVE was truly felt on screen with Alex Haley parents,(simon and bertha.)But yea;The rest was "ok" but i like again,can repeatedly watch SIMON STORY WITH IRENE CARA CHARACTER,was such a great piece of ROOTS the next generation.,Best IMO of entire series for this chapter..Queen is incredible,i can't wait to see it on BET wed.all morning afternoon.Such a great ending to his incredible family-story being told.QUEEN i will be too watching on BET tomorrow,this xmas,week,love queen each part.and we all know NOTHING COMPARE to such realism/brutality/and triumph in the 1st original ROOTS.but i love seeing how ALL of KUNTA KINTE DESCENDANTS,turn out i do love that,the most.Happy holidays!adios.
